item.description:
@MisfitTorah @Adderabbi Let me know how many sfaradim are convinced by his argument.

@MisfitTorah @Adderabbi You can’t say no God fearing Jew would eat kitniyot, because sfardim. You can’t say no God fearing Jew would eat chicken parm, because R’ Jose. So it’s not really goyish the way bacon or lime jello are.

@MisfitTorah @Adderabbi You have to have faith that rabbinic leadership can be trusted with making century long, irreversible judgement calls.

@MisfitTorah @Adderabbi If you’re seeing people leave observance for kitniyot, it’s not about the taiva. It’s about the system.

@MisfitTorah @Adderabbi And for kitniyot, the neo-sefardi approach is a subtle rejuggling of the system that bends it without breaking it.

@MisfitTorah @Adderabbi But it’s ultimately epistemological. How do we know (we should do) this?

@MisfitTorah But ultimately it’s the same complaint: not trusting the judgement of rabbinic leadership

@MisfitTorah Or more specifically, a rabbinic leadership that can only change in one direction.

@MisfitTorah Kitniyot lives in the past. A past where legumes and grains were stored together, and a past where we lived in the lands of ashkenaz and the custom was effectively universal.

@DBashIdeas First rabbi I ever sat in a class with.

@DBashIdeas Emory, slightly before I was born.

item.description:
@MisfitTorah Maybe I’m guilty of excess kav zechut, but I think if a dispensation came down from Heaven saying clal Yisrael can rewrite one chapter of the Shulchan Aruch, agunot would get more votes than kitniyot or chicken parm.

@MisfitTorah And all of us can potentially eat kitniyot, and the decision not to is a concrete one made in the supermarket every Nissan.

@dzkalman @shaisecunda This comes back to the sampling question. If there are a thousand frum Jews in town, and one is a landlord with ten thousand rental units, most appliance installations by a frum Jew will be by a landlord.

@dzkalman @shaisecunda There’s a line between stereotyping as bad statistics and antisemitism. Which is part of why defining antisemitism as unique rather than an example of group stereotyping obscures more than it clarifies.

item.description:
@dzkalman If you have 10 bad landlords and two are Orthodox Jews — as would happen on the old Village Voice lists — and let’s assume for a moment the list is based on an “objective” count of violations —

@dzkalman Then the two Jews will stand out more than the eight gentiles. But what is the real question?

@dzkalman Are a higher proportion of Jewish landlords bad than gentile landlords?

@dzkalman Are a higher percentage of Jews landlords, so even if each Jewish landlord is only half as likely to be bad as a gentile, there are still a disproportionate number of bad Jewish landlords?

@dzkalman And if there’s an implicit claim that being a religious Jew conveys virtue in a universal sense, isn’t one bad landlord sufficient to rebut that claim?

@dzkalman And given the tendency of Orthodox religious leaders to stereotype other groups — cf Avigdor Miller and RHS — is it appropriate for them to cry foul when they’re stereotyped in turn?

@dzkalman Haven’t there been studies showing people have a limited amount of goodness? And if you exhaust yours keeping two sets of dishes, casual fraud is that much harder to resist.

@dzkalman Thinking now of a scion of a well known modern Orthodox family whose financial records I had occasion to review. An awful lot of personal expenses paid by the business that weren’t reported as income on Schedule C.
